customer_journey.awareness: Patient realizes need through symptoms, insurance requirement, or preventive care reminder, searches for 'primary care doctor near me' or 'family physician accepting new patients', checks insurance provider directory and reads reviews focusing on wait times and bedside manner
customer_journey.consideration: Evaluates 3-5 practices based on insurance acceptance, location within 10 miles, appointment availability within 2 weeks, office hours compatibility, and online reviews above 4 stars, calls to verify new patient acceptance
customer_journey.decision: Selects practice offering soonest new patient appointment, convenient location, positive phone interaction, and ideally same-day sick visits, books appointment within 48 hours of initial search
customer_journey.retention: Maintains relationship for average 7-10 years, brings family members, schedules annual physicals, uses for all non-emergency medical needs
customer_journey.advocacy: Recommends to coworkers and neighbors seeking new PCP, leaves reviews after positive experiences, refers family members creating multi-generational patient families

educational.template:
🏥 ER vs. Urgent Care vs. Primary Care - When to go where?

Saw this question come up in our local [CITY] group and wanted to share a quick guide that could save you time, money, and stress:

🚨 GO TO THE ER FOR:
• Chest pain or difficulty breathing
• Severe bleeding or head injuries  
• Stroke symptoms (face drooping, arm weakness, speech difficulty)
• Severe allergic reactions
• Anything life-threatening

⚡ URGENT CARE IS GOOD FOR:
• Minor broken bones or sprains
• Cuts that need stitches
• Moderate fever or flu symptoms
• When your primary care is closed

💙 CALL YOUR PRIMARY CARE FOR:
• Ongoing symptoms (cough, rash lasting over a week)
• Chronic condition management
• Prescription refills
• Annual check-ups and preventive care
• Anything you want YOUR doctor (who knows your history) to evaluate

Here's the thing nobody tells you: An ER visit averages $2,000+ even for non-emergencies. Urgent care runs $150-300. A primary care visit? Usually $20-50 copay, sometimes $0.

At [PRACTICE NAME], we offer same-day sick appointments specifically so you don't have to choose between waiting weeks or paying ER prices.

authority.subject: What your doctor wishes you knew about prevention
authority.preview_text: 15 years in family medicine taught me this...
authority.body:
Hi [FIRST_NAME],

After 15 years in family medicine, I've learned something important:

The healthiest patients aren't the ones who never get sick. They're the ones who prevent problems before they start.

Here's what that actually looks like:

✅ ANNUAL PHYSICALS (yes, every year)
Catches high blood pressure, pre-diabetes, and high cholesterol before they cause damage. Usually covered 100% by insurance.

✅ AGE-APPROPRIATE SCREENINGS  
Colonoscopy, mammogram, skin checks - these find cancer when it's most treatable.

✅ MEDICATION REVIEWS
Prevents dangerous interactions and side effects. Especially important if you see multiple specialists.

✅ VACCINE UPDATES
Flu, pneumonia, shingles, COVID - these prevent serious illness and hospitalization.

✅ CHRONIC CONDITION MANAGEMENT
Regular monitoring keeps diabetes, hypertension, and other conditions under control.

THE TRUTH ABOUT PREVENTION:

It's not expensive - waiting is expensive.
It's not time-consuming - complications are time-consuming.  
It's not unnecessary - it's how you stay healthy long-term.

When was your last preventive visit?

If it's been over a year, let's get you scheduled:

To your health,

Dr. [NAME]
